am.pdf pdf false 1425111 AAM-PDF MCAT 112568 112568 S2468-8231(22)00454-0 10.1016/j.mcat.2022.112568 Fig. 1 Schematic illustration of the general synthesis of SOM-MOFs. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Synthesis of SOM-MOFs. (a) Schematic diagram of the strategy to design SOM-ZIF-8. THF, tetrahydrofuran. (b) Representative SEM image of SOM-ZIF-8 and SEM images of single crystals from different directions. (c) TEM images of SOM-ZIF-8 taken along the <011> zone axis with the corresponding SAED patterns showed in the inset of (c). Reproduced with permission [36]. Copyright 2018, American Association for the Advancement of Science. (d) Schematic synthesis process of ZIF-67 using SiO2 as a template. Reproduced with permission [45]. Copyright 2020, Wiley. (e) Schematic synthesis of the ordered macroporous-mesoporous Cu-BDC. Reproduced with permission [46]. Copyright 2019, Elsevier Inc. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Synthesis of SOM-MOF-based composites. (a) Schematic preparation of HRP-embedded SOM-ZIF-8. Reproduced with permission [51]. Copyright 2020, Royal Society of Chemistry. (b) Synthesis procedure for the IY-SO3H/Rh@SZIF-8. Reproduced with permission [53]. Copyright 2019, American Chemical Society. (c) Schematic representation for the preparation of NiFe MOF/OM-NFH. Reproduced with permission [55]. Copyright 2019, Wiley. (d) Schematic illustration of preparation of om-NENU-3a. Reproduced with permission [62]. Copyright 2021, American Chemical Society. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Synthesis of SOM-MOF derived carbon-immobilized single-atom sites. (a) Schematic synthesis of FeN4/HOPC-c-1000. (b) TEM image of FeN4/HOPC-c-1000, with the inset showing the corresponding SAED pattern. (c) AC-STEM images of FeN4/HOPC-c-1000. (d) Fourier transform Fe K-edge EXAFS spectra. Reproduced with permission [63]. Copyright 2020, Wiley. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Synthesis of SOM-MOF derived carbon-supported metal compounds. (a) Schematic illustration of the fabrication of 3DOM CdS QD/NC. (b, c) TEM images and (d) HRTEM image of 3DOM CdSQD/NC. Reproduced with permission [70]. Copyright 2021, Wiley. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Thermocatalytic applications of SOM-MOFs. (a) Confocal microscopy images at 1 min intervals to in-situ monitor the diffusion process of GFP through individual crystals of SOM-ZIF-8 and C-ZIF-8. (b) Benzaldehyde conversions over SOM-ZIF-8, C-ZIF-8, PH-ZIF-8, and M-ZIF-8 versus the reaction time. (c) Recyclability tests of SOM-ZIF-8 and PH-ZIF-8. Reproduced with permission [36]. Copyright 2018, American Association for the Advancement of Science. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Thermocatalytic applications of SOM-MOF-based composites. (a) CEES oxidation using H2O2 as the oxidation agent. (b) CEES conversion (solid) and ln(Ct/C0) (hollow) at different reaction time. (c) Recyclability test of om-NENU-3a in the oxidation of CEES. Each run was proceeded for 16 min. The inset showed the selectivity of om-NENU-3a and cm-NENU-3a. Reproduced with permission [62]. Copyright 2021, American Chemical Society. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Carbon composites with ordered macropores and hollow walls for hydrogenation reactions. (a) Schematic synthesis process of H-3DOMCo/NC. (b) The reaction pathway for the FFA hydrogenation to CPL. (c) The yield of CPL versus reaction time over different catalysts. (d) Proposed mechanism for FFA hydrogenation to CPL over the H-3DOM-Co/NC. Reproduced with permission [84]. Copyright 2021, Wiley. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Photocatalytic applications of SOM-MOF-based materials. (a) Comparison of the hierarchically ordered porous structure and its bulk counterpart. (b) Yield of cyclic carbonate versus time over various catalysts. Reproduced with permission [65]. Copyright 2020, Elsevier Inc. (c) Schematic illustration of the photocatalytic CO2 reduction integrated with selective arylamine oxidation reaction system. (d) Visible-light-driven CO2 reduction coupled with selective benzylamine oxidation under different reaction conditions. (e) Generation of CO, H2, and N-benzylbenzaldimine photocatalyzed by 3DOM CdSQD/NC versus reaction time. Reproduced with permission [70]. Copyright 2021, Wiley. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Electrocatalytic applications of SOM-MOF-based materials. (a) Schematic illustration of Fe/Ni–N x /OC with hetero-single-atoms and ordered macropores. (b, c) ORR polarization curves tested in (b) O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH and (c) O2-saturated 0.1 M HClO4 solution at a scan rate of 1600 rpm. Fig. 10 Review Ordered macroporous MOF-based materials for catalysis Xi Peng a Liyu Chen b ⁎ Yingwei Li b ⁎ a School of Chemistry, South China Normal University, Guangzhou 510006, China School of Chemistry South China Normal University Guangzhou 510006 China 1School of Chemistry, South China Normal University, Guangzhou 510006 China. b School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou 510640, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering South China University of Technology Guangzhou 510640 China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou 510640, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) possess various excellent properties. However, most MOFs exhibit microporosity, which restricts their applications in diffusion-related processes. Recently, single-crystal ordered macroporous MOFs (SOM-MOFs) have been successfully fabricated via monolith templates combined with heterogeneous nucleation approaches. SOM-MOFs exhibit improved mass transfer efficiency and catalytic activity compared with their microporous counterparts. SOM-MOFs can be integrated with other functional materials, including metal nanoparticles, polyoxometalates, and biomacromolecules, to enhance the characteristics of SOM-MOFs. Moreover, SOM-MOFs can act as ideal precursors and/or templates for the fabrication of ordered macroporous functional materials with well exposed active sites, good stability, and high conductivity. This review intends to offer an overview of recent advances in the synthesis of SOM-MOF-based nanomaterials and their applications in thermo-, photo-, and electrocatalysis, with particular emphasis on the discussion of the synthesis, properties, and structure–activity relationships. Furthermore, we propose the current challenges and future prospects of SOM-MOF-based materials. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Catalysis Hierarchically porous materials Metal–organic frameworks Mass transfer Ordered macroporous structures Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Porous materials with large surface area and high adsorption capacity have attracted significant attention in both scientific and industrial communities. Porous materials are widely applied in various scenarios, such as gas adsorption, separation, heterogeneous catalysis, sensing, biomedicine, and energy storage and conversion [1–5]. Among various porous structures, macroporous materials with pore sizes larger than 50 nm exhibit some unique physical and chemical properties [6–9]. In the case of ordered macroporous structures, the interconnected pores can provide fast mass transport, efficient accessibility of active centers, and fast electron transport for catalysis applications [10–15]. Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are a new class of porous materials constructed by inorganic metal nodes (metal ions or clusters) and organic linkers [16,17]. MOFs possess a variety of interesting properties, including high porosity, tunable compositions, and easy modification [18–25]. Nevertheless, the pore sizes of most MOFs are usually concentrated in the micropore range (< 2 nm), which significantly limit the applications of MOFs in diffusion-limited processes. Therefore, creating mesopores and macropores for hierarchically porous MOFs has attracted great interest [26–29]. Hierarchical MOFs with a random distribution of meso/macropores can enhance the mass transfer to some extent [30–34], but the disordered nature may result in the blockage of some pores to be accessed by the substrates. In addition, for some macroporous MOFs, the macropores are formed from the assembly of intergrown MOF polycrystals [35], which would be easily collapsed during applications. In 2018, we reported the first example of ordered macro-microporous MOF single crystal, denoted as SOM-MOFs (SOM represents single-crystal ordered macropore), which opened up the area of three-dimensional (3D)–ordered macro-microporous materials in the single-crystalline form [36]. The successful fabrication of SOM-MOFs relies on the employment of monolith templates combined with heterogeneous nucleation approaches (Fig. 1 ). The hierarchical frameworks exhibit efficient mass diffusion properties and robust single-crystalline nature, thus showing superior catalytic activity and stability in bulky-molecule-involved reactions. After that, significant progress has been achieved in the field of ordered macroporous MOF-based materials. SOM-MOFs can be integrated with other functional materials (e.g., metal nanoparticles (NPs), metal compounds, polyoxometalates (POMs), and biomacromolecules) to enhance the physical/chemical properties. SOM-MOF-based composites can not only combine both of the advantages of their counterparts, but also exhibit new properties due to the synergistic effect. Moreover, SOM-MOF-based materials can act as ideal precursors and/or templates for the synthesis of 3D-ordered macroporous (3DOM) carbon composites and metal compounds by pyrolysis and/or solvent thermal transformation. During the transformation, the 3D-ordered macroporous structures can be mostly preserved. But the inorganic nodes are converted to metal NPs/compounds or single metal atoms, which are readily exposed to substrates. The obtained SOM-MOF-based materials display significantly improved properties compared with conventional microporous MOF-based materials. 3D-ordered macroporous MOF-based materials have been successfully applied in various applications, especially heterogeneous catalysis (thermal-, photo-, electrocatalysis). In this review, we discuss the synthetic strategies of SOM-MOF-based materials (including SOM-MOFs, SOM-MOF-based composites, and their derivatives). The applications of SOM-MOF-based materials in the field of catalysis are also presented. The comparison of performance between the SOM-MOF-based materials and their microporous counterparts is made. The structure–performance relationships of SOM-MOF-based materials are detailly discussed. This review is aimed at encouraging continuous efforts in the development of SOM-MOF-based materials for applications in thermo-, photo-, and electrocatalysis. 2 Synthesis and characterization of SOM-MOF-based materials 2.1 Pristine SOM-MOFs For the synthesis of macro-mesoporous MOFs, several methods are developed, including nanocasting, etching, and defect-induced techniques [37–40]. However, these methods are hard to afford ordered macro-microporous MOF single crystals. Alternatively, the use of long ligands or 3D–ordered templates can achieve periodic meso- and macropores [27,35,41]. However, these meso- and/or macroporous MOFs suffered from rapid collapse due to their nonrigid or polycrystalline nature. Therefore, it is vital to develop an effective method to synthesize ordered macroporous MOF single crystal materials. Recently, we reported the first example of a 3D-ordered macro-microporous MOF single crystal [36]. The proposed strategy to obtain SOM-MOFs relied on the use of a polystyrene sphere (PS) monolith template and a double-solvent method to induce the assembly of MOF in the ordered voids of the PS monolith (Fig. 2a ). Highly ordered 3D PS monoliths were first assembled, followed by the filling of 2-methylimidazole and Zn(NO3)2 into the gap of the PS monoliths. After that, the "precursor@PS" was immersed in a mixed solution of CH3OH and NH3·H2O for the growth of ZIF-8. The use of double solvents is the key to realizing the nucleation and growth of the single-crystal MOF in the ordered voids of templates. NH3·H2O can accelerate the crystallization rate of the MOF, while CH3OH can effectively stabilize the precursor. Finally, after removing the template, a 3D-ordered ZIF-8 single crystal was obtained. SOM-ZIF-8 exhibited a highly ordered macroporous structure, with an average diameter of interconnected macropores of ∼270 nm (Fig. 2b). SOM-ZIF-8 possessed single-crystalline nature (Fig. 2c). SOM-ZIF-8 showed a typical type-I isotherm, implying its microporous structure, which was also verified by the corresponding size distribution curve. Mercury intrusion porosimetry showed that SOM-ZIF-8 had a regular large pore distribution with a pore window of ∼80 nm, implying its macroporous structure. In addition, the particle sizes of SOM-ZIF-8 increased from ∼1.3 to ∼4.3 µm by adjusting the volume ratio of NH3·H2O in the solution from 0.33 to 0.67. Moreover, by tuning the diameters of the PS templates, the macropore sizes of SOM-ZIF-8 materials could be readily adjusted from ∼190 to ∼470 nm. The monocrystalline 3D-ordered macro-microporous ZIF-8 synthesized by this method was more stable and less prone to collapse than polycrystal hollow ZIF-8 composed of intergrown polycrystals. The interconnected macropores in the SOM-ZIF-8 structure could effectively enhance the transfer of reactants to enter the framework and thus improve the catalytic activities. After that, Zhang and co-workers successfully extended this method for the synthesis of Co-based SOM-ZIF-67 by carefully controlling the nucleation rate [42]. In addition to ZIFs formed by imidazolate ligands with divalent metal ions, other kinds of carboxylate-based MOFs with ordered macroporous structures have been successfully prepared [43,44]. Xing, Li, and co-workers developed a solvent evaporation-induced self-assembly route to fabricate an ordered macroporous MIL-125 material [44]. In this method, isopropyl alcohol solution of titanium tetraisopropoxide and terephthalic acid was first immersed in the gap of PSs, followed by gradual evaporation of the solution for the crystallization of MIL-125. Macroporous MIL-125 possessed an interconnected macroporous structure with a macropore size of 280 nm. Macroporous MIL-125 had a very high porosity, with a Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) surface area of up to 1083 m2 g−1. Macroporous MIL-125 also showed excellent ultraviolet absorption ability, holding great promise to act as a photocatalyst. Besides using PS monolith as a template, silica nanosphere monolith can be used as a template to prepare ordered macroporous MOFs. Xia and co-workers reported the fabrication of interconnected macroporous ZIF-67 using SiO2 as a template [45]. In this method, silica nanospheres of different sizes from 330 to 350 nm were first impregnated with the cobalt source, followed by the addition of imidazole ligands (Fig. 2d). Then the mixture was heated for the assembly of precursors into ZIF-67. The successful fabrication of ZIF-67 in the voids of silica nanospheres should be attributed to the rich anchoring sites on the silica spheres. Moreover, it has been demonstrated that both ordered macropores and mesopores can be assembled into one MOF using double templates. Li, Yang, and co-workers reported a solvent evaporation-induced co-assembly route to fabricate ordered macro-mesoporous MOFs (macro-meso-Cu-BDC) using PS and block copolymers (P123) as the macropore and mesopore templates, respectively (Fig. 2e) [46]. The precursors of Cu-BDC were impregnated in the voids of the PS and P123 templates and assembled into Cu-BDC through an ethanol evaporation process. The material was then washed with DMF to eliminate the PS template to form a macroporous structure, followed by soaking in an acidic ethanol solution to remove the P123 template to create a mesoporous structure. Afterwards, Cu-BDC with a highly ordered macroporous, mesoporous and microporous structure was successfully synthesized, denoted as macro-meso-Cu-BDC. The macro-meso-Cu-BDC had an ordered arrangement of uniform macropores with a size of 265 nm and uniform mesoporous walls with a mesopore size of 4.1 nm. The unique hierarchical ordered pore structure of macro-meso-Cu-BDC could provide channels for mass transfer to improve mass transfer efficiency. The above examples for the fabrication of SOM-MOFs are generally based on the solvent thermal process. Very recently, it was demonstrated that an electrochemical deposition method was adequate for the synthesis of 3DOM ZIF-8 films [47]. The electrochemical process allowed the rapid and continuous synthesis of 3DOM ZIF-8 films under mild reaction conditions. As a summary, the monolith templates combined with heterogeneous nucleation approach is a powerful recipe to construct a variety of SOM-MOFs. The macropore sizes of SOM-MOFs can be tuned through changing the sphere diameters of monolith templates. The particle sizes of SOM-MOFs can be facilely adjusted by altering the ratios of double solvents. The key to the successful synthesis of SOM-MOFs relies on the construction of nanosphere monolith templates and good control over the nucleation and growth rates of MOFs for a revised replication of the porous structure of templates. The preparation of a monolith templates with dense packing and micrometre size is very important to obtain a micrometre-sized MOF with ordered macroporous structures. Filtration and centrifugation are two general methods for the construction of polystyrene/silica nanosphere monoliths. Filtration usually requires long time to achieve a dense packing of the polystyrene/silica nanospheres, while centrifugation cannot achieve a high yield. The development of efficient methods for the construction of monolith templates is desirable. Moreover, delicate control over the nucleation and growth of MOFs is required to allow the exclusive nucleation of MOFs in the voids of templates and growth into a single crystal. Metal precursors, ligands, solvents, pH, and temperatures are all important factors to determine the assembly of MOFs. For the successful fabrication of SOM-MOFs, it is needed to take all of these factors into consideration. 2.2 SOM-MOF-based composites SOM-MOFs can serve as a promising host matrix for the immobilization of various functional nanomaterials, e.g., NPs, metal compounds, POMs, biomacromolecules, and silica. Different strategies have been proposed for the fabrication of SOM-MOF-based composites, including ship-in-bottle, bottle-around-ship, and in situ synthesis. Ship-in-bottle strategy refers to the assembly of guest species in the pores of SOM-MOFs. The introduction of guest species to the pores of MOFs through impregnation is very straightforward and is widely used. For conventional MOFs with microporous structures, it is very difficult to introduce the guest species into the pores of MOFs due to the large diffusion resistance [48,49]. SOM-MOFs possess ordered macropores with lower diffusion resistance, which are very beneficial for the incorporation of guest species, especially those with large sizes, through an impregnation method [41,50-52]. Mo, Zang and co-workers demonstrated the potential of SOM-ZIF-8 for the encapsulation of an enzyme (e.g., horseradish peroxidase, HRP) (Fig. 3a ) [51]. SOM-ZIF-8 was soaked in deionized (DI) water to allow all the gaps of SOM-ZIF-8 to be filled with water by sonication and vacuum degassing. The MOF was dispersed in the aqueous solution containing HRP with shaking at ambient temperature to load HRP, which was then separated by centrifugation and rinsed with DI water to obtain SOM-ZIF-8 loaded HRP complex (HRP@SOM-ZIF-8). The crystalline structure of SOM-ZIF-8 remained unchanged, while the specific surface area and pore volume decreased slightly after enzyme immobilization. The HRP mainly occupied the macropores of SOM-ZIF-8. The stability test demonstrated that only 6% and 16% of HRP encapsulated in the macropores of SOM-ZIF-8 was lost after 4 h and 4 weeks, respectively, while half of the HRP deposited on the external surface of traditional ZIF-8 was lost after 12 h. Therefore, the confinement effect offered by the macropores of SOM-ZIF-8 can significantly improve the stability of HRP. As another example, metal NPs can be encapsulated in the macropores of SOM-MOFs. Wang, Zhang, and co-workers developed a core−shell colloidal crystal templating method to synthesize a yolk−shell nanoreactor consisting of macroporous ZIF-8 shell and sulfonated PS yolks immobilized with rhodium NPs (IY-SO3H/Rh@S-ZIF-8) (Fig. 3b) [53]. In this method, cross-linked polyethylene (CLPS) microspheres were first functionalized through reaction with H2SO4 to obtain CLPS-SO3H microspheres, which were then immersed in a tetraethoxysilane/water/ethanol solution to grow SiO2. This procedure was repeated several times for an increased thickness of the silica shell in CLPS-SO3H@SiO2. Subsequently, the CLPS-SO3H@SiO2 was subjected to centrifugation and dried to afford the monolithic CLPS-SO3H@SiO2 CS-CCTs, which was employed as templates for the growth of ZIF-8 to yield IY-SO3H@SiO2/S-ZIF-8 composite monolith. Finally, the middle silica layer was selectively etched with NaOH solution to obtain the IY SO3H@S-ZIF-8 material with a yolk–shell structure, serving as a support for the immobilization of Rh NPs with a size of 3.8 nm by immobilization and in situ reduction method. The 3D yolk–shell structure had a 3D connected framework with communicating channels between adjacent spherical voids, which enhanced the efficient mass transport and facilitated the accessibility to the metal sites. SOM-MOF-based composites can also be prepared by using functional materials as templates through the bottle-around-ship strategy [54–58]. This strategy requires the first construction of functional materials with 3D-ordered macroporous structures, followed by the assembly of MOFs on the pore wall of the functional materials. In this regard, the functional nanomaterials usually serve as sacrificed templates to direct the growth of MOFs on the surface of functional materials. As an example, Zhu and co-workers developed an in-situ assembly strategy to embed NiFe MOF nanosheets vertically inlaid into a 3D-ordered macroporous structure of NiFe hydroxide (denoted as NiFe MOF/OM-NFH) [55]. In this method, the NFH precursor was introduced into the gaps of the PS template by an impregnation method followed by the removal of the PS template to obtain the 3D-ordered macroporous OM-NFH (Fig. 3c). Then, NiFe MOF nanosheets were grown on OM-NFH templates by solvothermal reaction in a mixed solvent of N, N-dimethylformamide, ethanol, and water with a volume ratio of 10:1:1. The NiFe MOF/OM-NFH material prepared by this method had a unique structure of ultra-thin NiFe MOF nanosheets with an average thickness of 1.5 nm, which could allow the exposure of a large number of NiFe active sites for catalytic applications. SOM-MOF composites can be prepared by an in-situ encapsulation strategy, in which the MOF assembly and incorporation of guest species are achieved simultaneously. In this regard, it is required to control the nucleation and growth of MOFs in the voids of templates and avoid the disruption of guest species for the assembly of MOFs [59–61]. Liu, Liu and co-workers proposed an in-situ incorporation strategy to construct of interconnected ordered macro−microporous POM@MOF single crystals (denoted as om-NENU-na) (Fig. 3d) [62]. The authors used a polar solvent (e.g., methanol) to weaken the interaction between metal ions and POMs (H3PW12O40) through establishing hydrogen bonding with surface oxygens of POM. Therefore, the crystallization of MOFs before entering the gaps of PS templates could be effectively prevented. Meanwhile, sodium formate with suitable basicity was used to regulate the nucleation and growth rates of NENU-n. The obtained om-NENU-3a possessed highly ordered macroporous structures and good crystallinity. Different methods have been proposed for the synthesis of SOM-MOF-based composites. Given the large family of MOFs and plenty choice of functional materials, as well as different types of their combination, countless SOM-MOF-based composites can be prepared to satisfy the requirement of different applications. However, the preparation of SOM-based composites is still on the laboratory scale. The development of facile and simple method for the large-scale production of SOM-MOF-based compositions is important to realize their industrial applications. 2.3 SOM-MOF derivatives SOM-MOFs can be employed as templates and/or precursors for the fabrication of ordered macroporous carbon-based composites. The ordered macroporous structure of 3D macroporous MOF can be inherited to the derivatives in the transformation process. Moreover, the material obtained after transformation can provide more exposed metal active sites, allowing the derived material to exhibit excellent properties. SOM-MOFs can act as ideal precursors for the fabrication of ordered macroporous carbon-supported metal composites (metal NPs and single metal atoms, etc.) by pyrolysis [63–69]. Hu, Mamat, Wang, and co-workers employed Fe-doped ZIF-8 single crystals as precursors to fabricate a FeN4-doped hierarchical ordered porous carbon skeleton (denoted as FeN4/HOPC) through carbonization (Fig. 4a ) [63]. PS templates were first decorated with Fe3+ ions, which were used as templates for the synthesis of Fe-doped ordered macro/microporous single-crystalline ZIF-8 (OMS-FeZIF-8). Using OMS-FeZIF-8 as a precursor, ordered porous carbon skeletons decorated with atomically dispersed FeN4 centers (FeN4/HOPC) were obtained through carbonization under N2 flow. After carbonization, the size of interconnected macropores was reduced from 118 to 96 nm. Furthermore, a great number of mesopores were formed in the thin walls between macropores. N-coordinated FeN4 sites were homogeneously distributed in the carbon skeleton (Fig. 4b–d). The macro-, meso-, microporous structure of FeN4/HOPC provided a high surface area for the attachment of active sites and an interconnected network to enhance the mass transfer rate. SOM-MOFs can also be converted to carbon-supported metal compounds through carbonization followed by phase transformation. Zhang and co-workers fabricated 3D-ordered macroporous carbon-supported cobalt diselenide composites (3DOM CoSe2@C) using SOM ZIF-67 as a precursor and Se powder as Se sources [42]. Co-based ZIF-67 was first grown in the voids of 3D-ordered PS templates by a saturated solution-based double-solvent-assisted strategy. Then SOM-ZIF-67 was mixed with Se power and thermally treated in an Ar atmosphere to accomplish carbonization and selenization at the same time. 3DOM CoSe2@C had an ordered macroporous framework with sizes of macropores reduced from 190 to 140 nm after calcination. Furthermore, CoSe2 NPs with a size of 5 nm were evenly dispersed in the ordered macroporous carbon framework. N2 sorption isotherms of 3DOM CoSe2@C showed features of type-IV isotherm, implying the presence of both micropores and mesopores. The 3D-ordered macro-microporous structure could allow the exposure of abundant reactive centers and effectively accelerate the diffusion of ions in the reaction. In addition, a calcination followed by ion exchange process was proposed for the synthesis of carbon-supported metal compounds from SOM-MOFs. We fabricated a composite consisted of CdS quantum dots immobilized on 3D-ordered macroporous N-doped carbon (denoted as 3DOM CdSQD/NC) using SOM-ZIF-8 as the precursor [70]. First, SOM-ZIF-8 was converted to 3DOM N-doped carbons supported with ZnO QDs (denoted as 3DOM ZnOQD/NC) through pyrolytic treatment at 350 °C under air atmosphere. 3DOM ZnOQD/NC was further treated in S2− anion and Cd2+ cation solution in sequence to obtain 3DOM CdS QD/NC (Fig. 5a ). 3DOM CdS QD/NC inherited the ordered macroporous structure from 3DOM ZnOQD/NC with a uniform aperture of about 160 nm (Fig. 5b, c). Uniform and discrete CdS QDs (4.5 nm) were homogeneously dispersed on the whole 3DOM NC skeleton (Fig. 5d). The 3DOM CdS QD/NC material prepared by this method exhibited abundant catalytically active sites, high light absorption capacity, and effective charge separation efficiency. Bi, Zhang, and co-workers applied a similar approach for the preparation of copper sulfide immobilized on a 3D-ordered macroporous carbon framework (3DOM Cu9S5@C) through a sulfidation and subsequent ion exchange process using SOM-ZIF-8 as a precursor [71]. The as-synthesized 3DOM Cu9S5@C displayed an ordered macroporous structure with macropore size of ∼180 nm, which was decorated with a mass of Cu9S5 NPs with an average size of 7 nm. SOM-MOFs serve as a versatile platform for the fabrication of various functional nanomaterials. Pyrolysis and solvent thermal transformation are widely employed for the conversion of SOM-MOFs to 3D-ordered macroporous materials. It is required to pay more attention to avoid the collapse of ordered macroporous structures during the transformation. In addition, up to date, SOM-MOFs are only employed for the synthesis of 3DOM-carbon composites. It is expected to employ SOM-MOFs for the fabrication of 3DOM-metal compounds. 3 Catalytic applications SOM-MOF-based materials featured with 3D-ordered macroporous structures show a variety of interesting properties, which should be very beneficial for the applications in various fields, including gas storage/separation, heterogeneous catalysis, energy storage and conversion, biomedicine, and sensing. Here, we focus on discussing their applications in thermo-, photo-, and electrocatalysis. Heterogeneous catalysts play a vital role in proceeding a reaction. An efficient heterogeneous catalyst should possess efficient mass transfer efficiency, abundant active sites, and high intrinsic activity. In the field of catalysis, MOF materials can act as promising catalysts for many reactions because of their high surface area, tunable functionalization, open metal sites, and well-defined crystalline structure [72–83]. However, most MOFs fall into the microporous range, thus significantly limiting mass transfer and accessibility of active sites. SOM-MOFs possess ordered macroporous structures, which are beneficial for efficient mass diffusion with high catalytic activity. 3.1 Thermocatalysis SOM-MOF-based materials have been successfully employed as heterogeneous catalysts in different thermal-driven reactions, such as coupling reactions, oxidation reactions, and hydrogenation reactions. The catalytic activity of 3D-ordered macroporous ZIF-8 single crystal was first explored by Li, Chen, and co-workers for the Knoevenagel condensation reaction between benzaldehydes and malononitriles [36]. SOM-ZIF-8 showed extremely high catalytic performance, achieving a full conversion of benzaldehyde within 2 h (Fig. 6b ). For comparison, conventional bulk ZIF-8 required 8 h to achieve a total transformation of benzaldehyde. Under identical reaction conditions. SOM-ZIF-8 also outperformed many microporous catalysts like amino-functionalized molecular sieves and UiO-66-NH2. To further demonstrate the role of interconnected macropores in the mass transfer, a green fluorescent protein (GFP) was employed to study the diffusion efficiency of SOM-ZIF-8 and C-ZIF-8 crystals. The experimental results showed that GFP diffused through the SOM-ZIF-8 crystal much faster than the C-ZIF-8 crystal, verifying the enhanced diffusion efficiency of 3D-ordered macropores for large molecules (Fig. 6a). In addition, SOM-ZIF-8 showed high stability and reusability, with only an 8% decrease in the conversion of benzaldehyde in the seventh run. Comparably, polycrystal hollow ZIF-8 exhibited a 5% decrease of activity in every run (Fig. 6c). This work demonstrated that the 3D-ordered macroporous structure of SOM-ZIF-8 was beneficial to mass transfer for the improvement of catalyst activity, and the single-crystal structure of SOM-ZIF-8 endowed it with excellent stability. The catalytic activity of SOM-MOF can be greatly enhanced through integrating functional materials. For SOM-MOF-based compositions, the functional guest species provide catalytically active sites, and the porous network of SOM-MOFs can provide a highway for efficient mass diffusion and good accessibility of active sites. For example, Liu and co-workers constructed hierarchically ordered macro-microporous POM@MOF single crystals (om-NENU-3a) for bulky molecule-involved oxidation reactions [62]. om-NENU-3a had a macroporous structure, effectively enhancing the mass transport and providing a high number of exposed active sites. Compared with conventional microporous NENU-3a (cm-NENU-3a), om-NENU-3a exhibited a similar adsorption capacity for methanol molecules, but a faster adsorption rate for butanol molecules with the time to reach adsorption saturation nearly 10 h earlier than that of cm-NENU-3a. In addition, NH3-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) experiment showed that the desorption temperature of NH3 in om-NENU-3a was lower than that of cm-NENU-3a, indicating that the 3D-ordered macropores were favorable for the diffusion of NH3. Moreover, Om-NENU-3a had a larger desorption peak area, implying that it had more acidic sites. Fluorescein isothiocyanate-labeled bovine serum albumin (BSA, 5 × 5 × 7 nm) was chosen to study the mass transfer rate of cm-NENU-3a and om-NENU-3a. The result found that the biological macromolecule BSA could be transferred in the macropores structure of om-NENU-3a rapidly, but could not diffuse into the microporous structure of cm-NENU-3a. Therefore, the ordered macroporous meshes in om-NENU-3a could effectively facilitate the mass transfer. Furthermore, the catalytic activity of om-NENU-3a was studied in the oxidation of bulky 2-chloroethyl ethyl sulfide (CEES) (Fig. 7a ). om-NENU-3a exhibited high catalytic activity, achieving a complete conversion of CEES in 16 min with a reaction rate constant of 0.31 min−1. For comparison, cm-NENU-3a only showed a conversion of 58.9% with a rate constant of 0.05 min−1 under similar conditions (Fig. 7b). Overall, om-NENU-3a effectively improved the diffusion efficiency of substances in the framework due to its ordered macroporous structure, providing more active sites. The single-crystal nature of om-NENU-3a enabled its high stability and reusability over multiple catalytic reaction cycles (Fig. 7c). Moreover, for SOM-MOF-based catalysts, the hierarchically macro-microporous MOF network can synergistically work to enhance the activity and selectivity, in which the macropores can improve the diffusion kinetics and micropores can control the size selectivity of substrates. We prepared 3DOM-Pt@ZIF-8/SiO2 composites with ordered macroporous structure via a nanocasting method [54]. 3DOM-Pt@ZIF-8/SiO2 inherited the ordered macroporous structure from 3DOM-Pt/ZnO/SiO2. Pt NPs were homogeneously encapsulated in the as-formed ZIF-8. The BET surface areas (912.6 m2 g−1) and total pore volumes (0.475 cm3 g−1) of 3DOM-Pt@ZIF-8/SiO2 were largely improved compared with 3DOM-Pt/ZnO/SiO2. Benefited from the molecular sieve effect offered by the ZIF-8 shell, 3DOM-Pt@ZIF-8/SiO2 exhibited excellent size selectivity in the olefin hydrogenation reaction. 3DOM-Pt@ZIF-8/SiO2 and Pt/ZIF-8 (obtained by impregnation method) showed similar catalytic activities in the hydrogenation of 1-hexene. However, in the case of ciscyclooctene with a larger size than the pore of ZIF-8, 3DOM-Pt@ZIF-8/SiO2 could prohibit the hydrogenation of ciscyclooctene, while Pt/ZIF-8 showed a conversion of 24.9%. Moreover, 3DOM-Pt@ZIF-8/SiO2 could retain its activity in the hydrogenation of 1-hexene even after the seventh run. Therefore, in 3DOM-Pt@ZIF-8/SiO2, the ZIF-8 shell could serve as molecular sieve for size selectivity and protect the aggregation of Pt NPs, while SiO2 could act as a robust framework for protecting the entire 3DOM architecture from collapse. SOM-MOF-derived functional nanomaterials exhibit enhanced stability and an increased number of exposed active sites, which have also been successfully applied in organocatalysis. Guo et al. fabricated single Co atoms immobilized on N-doped hierarchically ordered porous carbon (Co-SAs@NHOPC) using single-crystalline ordered macro-microporous bimetallic ZnCo-ZIFs (OMS-ZnCo-ZIFs) as precursors for the selective hydrogenation of quinoline [64]. Co-SAs@NHOPC possessed ordered macroporous structures with atomic Co sites deposited on the thin pore walls. The as-prepared Co-SAs@NHOPC was applied in the selective hydrogenation of quinoline at 100 °C under 2 MPa of H2. The Co-SAs@NHOPC could efficiently convert quinoline to the 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline product with a yield of 99% in 3 h, superior to those of Co-NPs@NHOPC (82%), Co-SAs@NC (66%), Co-NPs@NC (42%). The superior performance of Co-SAs@NHOPC should be resulted from the catalytically active single-atomic metal sites and the hierarchically porous structure. The interconnected macropores could not only benefit the mass transportation to access the active centers, but also increase the concentration of quinoline around the active centers. Although the interconnected macroporous structure can greatly improve long-range mass transport, the thick microporous walls still restrict the availability of local active sites. In view of this, we reported a composite of Co NPs supported on nitrogen-doped carbon supports with 3D-ordered macroporous and hollow-wall structures (denoted as H-3DOM-Co/NC) to facilitate the availability of active sites [84]. We proposed a core–shell SOM-MOF-mediated route for the construction of hierarchically porous carbon composites. Core–shell SOM-ZIF-8@ZIF-67 crystal was first fabricated by epitaxial growth of ZIF-67 layers on the surface of SOM-ZIF-8, which was used as a precursor for the H-3DOM-Co/NC by calcination in an inert atmosphere (Fig. 8a ). In the process of thermal transformation, the 3D-ordered macroporous structure was largely preserved. Meanwhile, the walls of macropores showed a change from solid to hollow with Co NPs decorated in the walls. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) images showed that small Co NPs (4.9 nm) were uniformly distributed on the NC support. N2 sorption isotherm of H-3DOM-Co/NC exhibited the features of macroporous and mesoporous structures, with a BET surface area of 299 m2 g−1. Three comparative materials, including microporous C-Co/NC, mesoporous H-Co/NC, and mesopore-free 3DOM-Co/NC, were prepared to explore the role of unique porous structure of H-3DOM-Co/NC. In the hydrogenation of furfural, all catalysts exhibited identical selectivities to cyclopentanol, but different conversions. H-3DOM-Co/NC showed a conversion of 97.2%, much higher than those of 3DOM-Co/NC (62.3%), H-Co/NC (41.7%), and C-Co/NC (21.3%) (Fig. 8b–d). H2-TPD results demonstrated that mesopores improved the accessibility of Co sites. Moreover, the interconnected macropores could greatly facilitate the long-distance mass transfer. Therefore, H-3DOM-Co/NC with both macropores and mesopores could enhance the long-range mass transport and facilitate local accessibility of active Co sites, thereby synergistically improving catalytic activity. Furthermore, by adjusting the size of PSs, H-3DOM-Co/NC materials with different macropore and mesopore sizes could be facilely adjusted. The catalytic activity was improved with the increase of macropore and mesopore sizes, which should be owing to the improved mass transport efficiency and increased number of accessible active sites. Hot filtration experiments showed negligible Co species in the reaction mixture and no further conversion of furfural after removing the catalysts, demonstrating the heterogeneous nature of the catalytic system. Moreover, H-3DOM-Co/NC exhibited stable performance even after the seventh run. The reused catalysts exhibited neglected leaching and aggregation of Co NPs, which should be attributed to the confinement effect offered by the hierarchical porous nitrogen-doped carbon support. Therefore, the ordered interconnected macroporous carbon support could effectively enhance long-distance mass transport, and the hollow walls could promote the local accessibility of active sites. In addition, the N dopant on the carbon support could well stabilize the Co NPs, resulting in high stability and reusability in the catalytic reactions. SOM-MOF-based catalysts with ordered macroporous structures can enhance diffusion kinetics and accessibility of active centers, and thus greatly enhancing the catalytic efficiency. The present studies mainly focus on the study of structure–performance relationships using small molecules as substrates. SOM-MOF-based catalysts may offer a promising platform for bulky molecule-involved transformation. Future studies on the applications of SOM-MOF-based catalysts for biomass upgrading and pharmacological production are highly needed. Moreover, the shaping of SOM-MOF-based materials is very important when they are applied in industrial applications [85–87]. However, the macroporous structures may suffer from collapsing under high pressure. The development of SOM-based catalysts with high mechanical stability is of vital importance to satisfy their industrial applications. 3.2 Photocatalysis Photocatalysis can harvest and store solar energy in the form of chemical fuels and value-added fine chemicals [88–90]. The photocatalytic process involves the first uptake of light by a photosensitiser to reach the excited state, followed by the production of an electron and a hole, and finally the reaction of the substrate with the mobile electron or hole. The light-harvesting ability, charge mobilities, intrinsic activity, and accessibility of active sites are essential factors in determining the activity of photocatalysts. MOFs combine the advantages of inorganic semiconductors and organic molecular photocatalysts [91–97]. Pristine MOFs can be directly used as photocatalysts. Especially, SOM-MOFs with ordered hierarchical macroporous structures have high light absorption and high mass transfer efficiency, which can significantly boost the photocatalytic activity [98]. Xing, Li and co-workers applied the highly ordered hierarchical macro-porous MIL-125 for photocatalytic CO2 fixation [44]. In the carbonylative coupling reaction of 4-methylbenzyl chloride with CO2, MIL-125 achieved a yield of up to 76% under UV light (365 nm) and 0.1 MPa CO2, while only 16% yield could be obtained in the absence of UV irradiation. Microporous MIL-125 only gave a low yield of 39%. Moreover, macroporous MIL-125 showed a good substrate tolerance, enabling the carbonization coupling reactions of various benzyl halides and CO2 with good to excellent yield. The excellent catalytic performance of macroporous MIL-125 should be attributed to its hierarchically porous structure with enhanced diffusion efficiency and excellent UV absorption capacity. For the SOM-MOFs with low photoactivity, it can be integrated with functional nanomaterials (e.g., semiconductors and photosensitizers) to construct SOM-MOF composites for photocatalysis. Zhang and co-workers constructed a photocatalyst with ZIF-8 nanocrystals (NCs) deposited on 3D-ordered macroporous TiO2 (ZIF-8@3DOM TiO2), which was utilized for the one-pot aromatic alcohol oxidization-Knoevenagel condensation cascade reaction by illumination at ambient temperature [56]. In the conversion of benzyl alcohol to benzylic aldehydes, ZIF-8@3DOM TiO2 showed a conversion of 98%, higher than the random catalysts (90%) and 3DOM TiO2 (58%). In the Knoevenagel condensation reaction, ZIF-8@3DOM TiO2 still had the highest yield (98.0%) among the three catalysts. The random mixture catalyst was less active with a yield of 89.0%, while 3DOM TiO2 showed no catalytic activity. The UV-vis spectrum of ZIF-8@3DOM TiO2 showed enhanced visible light absorption compared with the random mixture and their single counterparts. These results demonstrated that ZIF-8 NCs and 3DOM TiO2 cooperatively worked to promote the cascade reaction. ZIF-8 NCs could promote the photocatalytic oxidation of alcohol catalyzed by 3DOM TiO2, and the ZIF-8 NCs could further proceed the Knoevenagel condensation reaction efficiently. Furthermore, ZIF-8@3DOM TiO2 was stable and recyclable, showing no significant decrease in activity after being reused for at least 5 runs. In addition, SOM-MOFs derived functional nanomaterials have been employed as effective catalysts in photocatalytic reactions. Wang, Zhang, and co-workers fabricated atomically dispersed Zn sites on N-doped hierarchically ordered porous carbon polyhedrons (Zn-N-HOPCPs) by the calcination of SOM-ZIF-8 [65]. Zn-N-HOPCPs displayed an ordered macroporous structure with interconnected pores between neighbour macropores. Single atomic Zn sites were evenly dispersed on the N-doped carbon supports. Zn-N-HOPCPs exhibited a wide range of light absorption from 230 to 800 nm, which covered the region of ultraviolet and visible light. In the photocatalytic cycloaddition of CO2 with propylene oxide, Zn-N-HOPCPs afforded a yield of 95% with tetrabutylammonium bromide as the co-catalyst at room temperature and atmospheric pressure (Fig. 9a , b). However, the yield dropped to 5% under the dark condition, indicating the critical role of photothermal effect on the catalytic system. N-HOPCPs exhibited lower activity, demonstrating the indispensable role of Zn atom as Lewis acid site. For comparison, Zn on N-doped hierarchically ordered porous carbon monolith, fabricated by using monolithic 3DOM-ZIF-8 as the template, only afforded a yield of 87%, indicating that the micron-sized supports were more effective to light absorption. The catalytic system showed no further conversion after removing the Zn-N-HOPCPs catalyst, indicating the heterogeneous nature of Zn-N-HOPCPs. Overall, the macro-, meso- and microporous structures of Zn-N-HOPCPs could significantly enhance the mass transfer of macromolecules, facilitate the exposure of active sites, and enhance the light-harvesting ability, thus resulting in superior CO2 photoconversion. Carbon-supported metal compounds derived from SOM-MOFs can be also employed as effective photocatalysts. We proposed an in-situ transformation method to fabricate ultrafine CdS QDs immobilized on a 3D-ordered macroporous N-doped carbon support (3DOM CdSQD/NC) for efficient photocatalytic CO2 reduction (Fig. 9c) [70]. 3DOM CdSQD/NC showed an ordered macroporous structure with a macropore size of ∼180 nm. CdS QDs with a size of 4.5 nm were homogeneously dispersed on the N-doped carbon support. Typically, the photocatalytic CO2 reaction was firstly conducted in a mixed solution of acetonitrile and water by using Co(2,2′-bipyridine)3 2+ as the co-catalyst without the assistance of sacrificial agents or additives. To further promote the photocatalytic CO2 reduction, an amine oxidation reaction process was employed to replace the oxygen evolution reaction for synergistic production of value-added imines. 3DOM CdSQD/NC furnished a high CO production rate of 5210 µmol g−1 h−1 with 89.6% selectivity (Fig. 9d, e). Besides, a formation rate of 9820 µmol g−1 h−1 to N-benzylbenzaldimine with 95.3% selectivity was achieved over 3DOM CdSQD/NC. Comparatively, microporous solid CdSQD/NC and nonporous bulky CdS materials only afforded moderate photocatalytic activity in the CO2-aminephotoredox reaction. 3DOM CdSQD/NC showed an apparent quantum yield of 2.9% in CO generation at 450 nm, outperforming the previous photocatalytic systems even with the use of sacrificial agents. Moreover, 3DOM CdSQD/NC still exhibited an excellent photocatalytic performance in a diluted CO2 atmosphere (10% CO2) with a generation rate of CO and N-benzylbenzaldimine of 1780 and 7560 µmol g−1 h−1, respectively, implying its potential in the application of exhaust gas removal. The integration of highly dispersed quantum dots and 3DOM structures endowed the 3DOM CdSQD/NC material with abundant exposed active sites, high light absorption, and excellent charge separation efficiency for the excellent catalytic performance in photocatalytic CO reduction and amine oxidation without any sacrificial or basic additives. Photocatalytically active SOM-MOF-based materials can simultaneously achieve the high accessibility of active sites, reinforced light harvesting, and rapid charge transfer. SOM-MOF-based photocatalysts have exhibited high activity in several organic reactions and CO2 transformation. The applications of SOM-MOF-based catalysts for photodegradation to remove pollutants and photocatalytic water splitting remain to be explored. 3.3 Electrocatalysis Electrocatalysis is a key process in various electrochemical energy storage devices and the electrosynthesis of renewable chemicals and fuels [99–101]. An efficient electrocatalyst requires active sites with high intrinsic activity, well-designed morphology to facilitate the mass transfer, and high electrical conductivity [102–105]. The direct use of pristine MOFs as electrocatalysts is usually limited by the low electronic conductivity and low chemical stability [106–109]. To address this issue, MOFs can be integrated with conductive substrates to facilitate effective electron transfer [57]. In addition, MOFs can also be converted to highly conductive carbon-based composites as effective electrocatalysts. In this regard, the pyrolysis of SOM-MOFs can yield electrically conductive carbon-based materials that retain their ordered macroporous structure, and the tunable heteroatoms and metal-based species can lead to high electrocatalytic activity towards various reactions [110]. Therefore, SOM-MOF-derived carbon-based materials are ideally suitable to serve as efficient electrocatalysts, and an overview on SOM-MOF derivatives for electrocatalysis will be presented in this section. Electrocatalytic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) has been widely investigated for energy applications. The reduction of oxygen to water through the four-electron pathway is the critical process in fuel cells and aqueous metal–air batteries [111,112]. The multi-step electron transfer and the diffusion of insoluble oxygen bring about significant resistance for ORR, resulting in large overpotential and low current density [113,114]. Therefore, efficient electrocatalysts are strongly required to boost the ORR process and thus enhance the performance of related energy devices. Through the rational design of active sites and morphology, SOM-MOF-derived materials have demonstrated their high activities for ORR, and have also been employed in practical devices like Zn–air batteries and hydrogen fuel cells [67, 115]. Zhang et al. synthesized efficient SOM-MOF-derived ORR electrocatalysts named 3DOM Fe–N–C, which composed of hierarchically micro-, meso-, and macroporous nitrogen-doped carbon embedded with FeN4 atomic sites [66]. The electrocatalyst obtained by pyrolyzing ferrocene-encapsulated SOM-ZIF-8 at 900 °C, namely 3DOM Fe-NC-900, exhibited superior ORR activity in both alkaline media (with an ORR half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.875 V vs reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE)) and acidic media (E 1/2 = 0.784 V). This electrocatalyst also showed high stability with only 2 mV change on E 1/2 after a cyclic voltammetry (CV) test in alkaline media for 10,000 cycles. When serving as the air electrode in Zn–air batteries, 3DOM-Fe-N-C-900 exhibited excellent discharge performance. The power density of the Zn–air battery was 235 mW cm−2 and the specific capacity was 768.3 mAh g−1. The single-atom Fe–N–C sites are considered as highly active for ORR electrocatalysis. The hierarchical 3D porous architecture of 3DOM-Fe-N-C-900 can enhance the mass transport and increase the accessibility of active sites, thus making full use of the Fe–N–C sites, and leading to superior performance in ORR and Zn–air batteries. Another representative work of SOM-MOF-derived ORR electrocatalysts with single Fe sites was reported by Wang, Mamat, Hu, et al. [63]. The ordered macropores were also generated with the assistance of PS templates. The Fe3+ ions were adsorbed on PSs and were introduced into ZIF-8 during the synthesis of the ordered porous single-crystal MOF. During the subsequent pyrolysis process, the ordered porous structure was retained. Due to the introduction of macro- and mesopores, abundant defect sites are formed, which effectively resisted the migration and accumulation of metals, resulting in uniformly distributed Fe single-atom sites. Through regulations on the pyrolysis temperature and the Fe-doping level in ZIF-8, FeN4/HOPC (hierarchically ordered porous carbon) catalysts with different carbon graphitization degrees and different contents of Fe sites could be obtained. The ORR activity of FeN4/HOPC was maximized by optimizing the composition and structure, with a E 1/2 of 0.80 V vs RHE in 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte, which was only slightly lower than commercial Pt/C (0.82 V). In practical proton-exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs), FeN4/HOPC exhibited significantly improved current density and power density compared with FeN4/C (obtained from the pyrolysis of Fe-doped ZIF-8) without ordered pores. These results implied that the ordered porous structure could enhance mass transfer and increase the utilization efficiency of active sites. Besides SOM-MOF-derived carbon materials with single-type metal doping, SOM-MOF-derived hetero-single-atom ORR electrocatalysts involving two different metal sites were reported by Zhao, Yin et al. (Fig. 10a ) [116]. In this work, ZIF-8 crystals were grown on a 3D-ordered PS template with the presence of Fe3+ and Ni2+ ions. The Fe and Ni doped ZIF-8 was then pyrolyzed to obtain a hierarchically porous N-doped carbon support with ordered macroporous structures and Fe and Ni single-atom sites (Fe/Ni–N x /OC). In ORR tests conducted in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH and 0.1 M HClO4 electrolytes, Fe/Ni–N x /OC exhibited an extremely high E 1/2 of 0.938 V and 0.840 V vs RHE, respectively, which were much better than its counterparts without metal doping and with single-type Fe or Ni doping (Fig. 10b, c). Density functional theory (DFT) calculations unveiled the electronic interaction between adjacent Ni–N4 and Fe–N4 sites through the conjugated π bond of graphene, which efficiently regulated the electronic structure of Fe atoms and thus improved the ORR performance. Meanwhile, the role of the hierarchical pore structure on ORR electrocatalysis was studied using electrocatalysts with different pore sizes, which were synthesized based on PSs with different diameters. The results indicated that an optimized size of PS templates could lead to a 3D hierarchical porous structure with both mesopores and macropores, facilitating the mass transfer and active site exposure during ORR. With superior ORR performance, Fe/Ni–N x /OC was also employed in Zn–air batteries, H2–O2 fuel cells, and H2–air fuel cells (Fig. 10d), exhibiting excellent discharge performances. ORR occurs on the air electrode of aqueous metal–air batteries during discharge. While during the charging process, the air electrode undergoes oxygen evolution reaction (OER), in which water is oxidized to oxygen. OER is also a 4e− electrocatalytic process with high overpotential and sluggish kinetics [117]. Therefore, bifunctional electrocatalysts for both ORR and OER are needed to achieve efficient rechargeable metal–air batteries [118]. Xia et al. proposed the synthesis of ZIF-derived ordered macroporous carbon (ZOMC) as a bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst through the pyrolysis of silica templated ZIF-67 [45]. The as-obtained ZOMC possessed abundant exposed cobalt-nitrogen-carbon active sites. The 3D-ordered carbon matrix with interconnected macropores could largely improve the accessibility of active sites and thus enhance mass transfer during electrocatalytic processes. In 0.1 M KOH electrolyte, ZOMC showed an overpotential to achieve the current density of 10 mA cm−2 (E 10) for OER of 1.56 V vs RHE, and an E 1/2 for ORR of 0.85 V vs RHE (Fig. 10e and f). The ORR/OER bifunctional activity can be evaluated by the potential difference (ΔE) between E 10 and E 1/2. ZOMC showed high bifunctional activity with a ΔE of 0.71 V, which was much lower than commercial Pt/C (0.9 V) and ZIF-67 NPs derived single polyhedron nanocarbon (0.85 V). The excellent dual function of ZOMC was expected to contribute to the discharge/charge properties of rechargeable Zn–air batteries. The use of ZOMC as the air electrode resulted in a small voltage gap during the discharging/charging process, and a high power density of 221.1 mW cm−2 (Fig. 10g). The ZOMC electrode also demonstrated excellent durability of 500 cycles (160 h) in a discharge/charge test with a constant current density at 5 mA cm−2, and the initial voltage gap was only 0.52 V, which was slightly increased to 0.76 V after 500 cycles. In addition to the applications in rechargeable metal–air batteries, OER is also a critical reaction in electrochemical water splitting [119]. Electrochemical water splitting is a promising technique to produce green hydrogen energy, with OER on the anode and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER, the reduction of water to hydrogen) on the cathode [120]. SOM-MOF-derived materials have also demonstrated their high activity for OER and HER, and the potential for the applications in electrochemical water splitting [68]. Zhu, Xu, and co-workers used a dual-solvent-based heterogeneous nucleation approach to prepare Ru(III)/MSC-ZIF-8 that consisted of ordered ZIF-8 macroporous single crystals incorporated with Ru(III) ions [69]. Ru(III)/MSC-ZIF-8 was then pyrolyzed to synthesize Ru nanoclusters (NCs) immobilized onto N-doped carbon with ordered macroporous structure, denoted as Ru/OMSNNC. Homogeneously distributed Ru NCs with an average size of ∼1.8 nm and ordered macropores with a diameter of ∼190 nm were observed by TEM analyses. N2 sorption measurements revealed the presence of abundant micro- and mesopores in Ru/OMSNNC with pore sizes at ∼1.1 and ∼3.8 nm, respectively. Ru/OMSNNC exhibited outstanding performance for HER electrocatalysis in 1.0 M KOH solution, which should be attributed to the abundant macro-, meso-, micropores and the uniform distribution of Ru NCs. Ru/OMSNNC showed a overpotential of only 13 mV at 10 mA cm−2 (η 10), much smaller than commercial Pt/C (32 mV), commercial Ru/C (62 mV), and Ru/NC derived from conventional ZIF-8 containing Ru(III) ions (131 mV). The favorable electrochemical properties of Ru/OMSNNC were also confirmed by the high electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) and low charge transfer resistance (R ct). To further investigate the advantages of Ru/OMSNNC in overall water splitting applications, Ru/OMSNNC was employed as the cathode in an H-type cell. The ordered macroporous superstructure RuO2 (OMS-RuO2) was used as the anode electrocatalyst, which was obtained through the pyrolysis of Ru/OMSNNC at 350 °C in the air (Fig. 10h). The Ru/OMSNNC||OMS-RuO2 electrode pair only needed a voltage of 1.7 V to drive the overall water splitting at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 10i), lower than Pt/C||OMS-RuO2 electrode pair (1.8 V at 10 mA cm−2). Under a wide voltage range from 1.6 V to 1.9 V, the H2 production rates of Ru/OMSNNC were nearly twice those of Pt/C. The Ru/OMSNNC||OMS-RuO2 electrolyzer also exhibited long-term stability for over 20 h under a constant current density of 20 mA cm−2, with the cell voltage and H2 production rate well maintained. According to the above results, Ru/OMSNNC and OMS-RuO2 were expected to be promising electrocatalysts for overall water splitting under alkaline condition. Considering the natural scarcity and high price of precious metals, Guo, Fang, Wu, and co-workers reported a SOM-MOF-derived electrocatalyst with non-precious transition-metal active sites for HER and OER [121]. This electrocatalyst consisted of uniformly dispersed Co/CoP NPs anchored in a hierarchically ordered macro-, meso- and microporous carbon substrate (Co/CoP@HOMC), which was obtained via the carbonization and phosphorization of PS-templated ZIF-67 precursor. Similar to the electrocatalysts introduced above in this section, the interconnected macroporous structure facilitated the electrolyte penetration and maximized the exposure of Co/CoP active sites during the electrocatalysis of HER and OER. In 1.0 M KOH electrolyte, Co/CoP@HOMC displayed superior bifunctional HER/OER performance, with η 10 of 120 and 260 mV for HER and OER, respectively. Co/CoP@HOMC then served as electrocatalyst for both cathode and anode materials in a two-electrode water splitting cell with 1 M KOH as the electrolyte. A cell voltage of only 1.54 V was required to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2. The water splitting activity could be maintained after potentiostatic electrolysis for 20 h. DFT calculations confirmed lower energy barriers for both HER and OER on Co/CoP heterojunction than on single Co and CoP sites. With highly active Co/CoP heterostructure and the hierarchically pore structure, the Co/CoP@HOMC material provided a good demonstration for the design of electrocatalysts from resourceful materials for overall water splitting. From the above discussions, we can find that the carbon supports with hierarchical ordered pores derived from the pyrolysis of SOM-MOFs can benefit the uniform dispersion of metal species and also facilitate the mass transport during electrocatalysis, thus exhibiting excellent electrocatalytic performances. However, the electrocatalytic applications of SOM-MOF-derived materials are still limited at present. It's expected to see SOM-MOF-derived materials demonstrating their superior performances in more electrocatalytic reactions, including CO2 reduction, N2 reduction, two-electron oxygen reduction, and so on. 4 Conclusions and future prospects SOM-MOFs possess ordered micro-macroporous structures and single-crystalline nature. An ordered monolith template combined with a double-solvent method is key to realizing the fabrication of SOM-MOFs. The double solvents can cooperatively adjust the assembly rate of MOFs in the gaps of monolith templates, thus allowing the formation of single-crystalline MOFs with ordered macropores replicated from the templates. The macropore size of SOM-MOFs can be readily tuned using a template with different diameters of spheres. Compared with their microporous MOF counterparts, SOM-MOFs exhibit enhanced diffusion kinetics and accessibility to active sites. SOM-MOFs can be integrated with other functional nanomaterials for SOM-MOF-based composites. SOM-MOF-based composites can not only exhibit both of the properties of their components, but also show synergistic effect for new physical and chemical properties. SOM-MOFs can also be employed as ideal precursors to prepare 3D-ordered macroporous functional materials. The porous structure of SOM-MOFs can be inherited to the derivatives, and the metal sites can be readily exposed to the substrate. The derived functional materials show enhanced stability and conductivity and an increased number of exposed metal sites. SOM-MOF-based materials (including pristine SOM-MOFs, SOM-MOF-based composites, and their derivatives) have been successfully applied in applications of thermo-, photo-, and electrocatalysis. SOM-MOF-based materials exhibit enhanced performance than their microporous counterparts. Although tremendous achievement has been made, the investigation of SOM-MOF-based materials in catalysis applications is still in its infancy and many important issues remain to be addressed. 1 The development of efficient and scalable strategies for the preparation of SOM-MOFs is desired. The fabrication of SOM-MOFs is only on the laboratory scale and still requires time-consuming procedures (including synthesis of template monolith, assembly of MOFs in the voids of templates, and removal of templates). As hard templates (e.g., PS monoliths) are necessary for the fabrication of SOM-MOFs, the investigation of facile strategy for the preparation of dense PS monoliths is a prerequisite for the scalable synthesis of SOM-MOFs. In addition, the procedure of assembly of MOFs in the voids of template monoliths and complete removal of templates should be simplified. 2 The mechanical stability of SOM-MOF-based materials should be enhanced before their consideration to be applied in industrial applications. Mechanical stability is essential for the shaping of SOM-MOF-based materials for industrial applications. The macroporous structures may suffer from collapse under high pressure. However, the studies of the mechanical properties of SOM-MOFs are overlooked. Integrating SOM-MOF-based materials with robust support (e.g., SiO2) may enhance the mechanical stability to prevent the ordered macroporous architecture from collapsing under pressure, which is deserved to be further investigated. 3 The structure-performance relationship of SOM-MOF-based materials requires further investigation. The mass diffusion rate of SOM-based materials should be carefully qualified. Moreover, traditional characterizations of SOM-MOF-based materials are based on ex situ methods, which cannot monitor the dynamics at working conditions. In operando methods are highly desirable for a comprehensive understanding of the working mechanisms. 4 The application of SOM-MOF-based materials to large molecule-involved transformation (e.g., biomass upgrading, pharmacological production) remains to be explored. SOM-MOF-based materials possess ordered macroporous structures, which are very beneficial for the diffusion of bulky molecules to access the active centers. The present research focuses on the simple evaluation of the activity of SOM-MOF-based materials using small molecules as a proof of concept. More effort to extend their applications to produce bulky and high-value-added products is desirable. Despite these challenges still exist, the rapid development of SOM-MOF-based functional materials endows a bright future for catalysis. Continuous research efforts in this exciting field are expected to enable their industrial applications. coredata.dc:description: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) possess various excellent properties. However, most MOFs exhibit microporosity, which restricts their applications in diffusion-related processes. Recently, single-crystal ordered macroporous MOFs (SOM-MOFs) have been successfully fabricated via monolith templates combined with heterogeneous nucleation approaches. SOM-MOFs exhibit improved mass transfer efficiency and catalytic activity compared with their microporous counterparts. SOM-MOFs can be integrated with other functional materials, including metal nanoparticles, polyoxometalates, and biomacromolecules, to enhance the characteristics of SOM-MOFs. Moreover, SOM-MOFs can act as ideal precursors and/or templates for the fabrication of ordered macroporous functional materials with well exposed active sites, good stability, and high conductivity. This review intends to offer an overview of recent advances in the synthesis of SOM-MOF-based nanomaterials and their applications in thermo-, photo-, and electrocatalysis, with particular emphasis on the discussion of the synthesis, properties, and structure–activity relationships. Furthermore, we propose the current challenges and future prospects of SOM-MOF-based materials.
coredata.dc:title: Ordered macroporous MOF-based materials for catalysis
